trans-unit.source: Use Azure Key Vault from a Web Application | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Use Azure Key Vault from a Web Application | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Use this tutorial to help you learn how to use Azure Key Vault from a web application.
trans-unit.target: Use this tutorial to help you learn how to use Azure Key Vault from a web application.

trans-unit.source: Use Azure Key Vault from a Web Application
trans-unit.target: Use Azure Key Vault from a Web Application

trans-unit.source: Introduction
trans-unit.target: Introduction

trans-unit.source: Use this tutorial to help you learn how to use Azure Key Vault from a web application in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Use this tutorial to help you learn how to use Azure Key Vault from a web application in Azure.

trans-unit.source: It walks you through the process of accessing a secret from an Azure Key Vault so that it can be used in your web application.
trans-unit.target: It walks you through the process of accessing a secret from an Azure Key Vault so that it can be used in your web application.

trans-unit.source: **Estimated time to complete:** 15 minutes
trans-unit.target: **Estimated time to complete:** 15 minutes

trans-unit.source: For overview information about Azure Key Vault, see [What is Azure Key Vault?](key-vault-whatis.md)
trans-unit.target: For overview information about Azure Key Vault, see [What is Azure Key Vault?](key-vault-whatis.md)

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: To complete this tutorial, you must have the following:
trans-unit.target: To complete this tutorial, you must have the following:

trans-unit.source: A URI to a secret in an Azure Key Vault
trans-unit.target: A URI to a secret in an Azure Key Vault

trans-unit.source: A Client ID and a Client Secret for a web application registered with Azure Active Directory that has access to your Key Vault
trans-unit.target: A Client ID and a Client Secret for a web application registered with Azure Active Directory that has access to your Key Vault

trans-unit.source: A web application.
trans-unit.target: A web application.

trans-unit.source: We will be showing the steps for an ASP.NET MVC application deployed in Azure as a Web App.
trans-unit.target: We will be showing the steps for an ASP.NET MVC application deployed in Azure as a Web App.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] It is essential that you have completed the steps listed in [Get Started with Azure Key Vault](key-vault-get-started.md) for this tutorial so that you have the URI to a secret and the Client ID and Client Secret for a web application.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] It is essential that you have completed the steps listed in [Get Started with Azure Key Vault](key-vault-get-started.md) for this tutorial so that you have the URI to a secret and the Client ID and Client Secret for a web application.

trans-unit.source: The web application that will be accessing the Key Vault is the one that is registered in Azure Active Directory and has been given access to your Key Vault.
trans-unit.target: The web application that will be accessing the Key Vault is the one that is registered in Azure Active Directory and has been given access to your Key Vault.

trans-unit.source: If this is not the case, go back to Register an Application in the Get Started tutorial and repeat the steps listed.
trans-unit.target: If this is not the case, go back to Register an Application in the Get Started tutorial and repeat the steps listed.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial is designed for web developers that understand the basics of creating web applications on Azure.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial is designed for web developers that understand the basics of creating web applications on Azure.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Azure Web Apps, see [Web Apps overview](../app-service-web-overview.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information about Azure Web Apps, see [Web Apps overview](../app-service-web-overview.md).

trans-unit.source: Add Nuget Packages
trans-unit.target: Add Nuget Packages

trans-unit.source: There are three packages that your web application needs to have installed.
trans-unit.target: There are three packages that your web application needs to have installed.

trans-unit.source: Active Directory Authentication Library - contains methods for interacting with Azure Active Directory and managing user identity
trans-unit.target: Active Directory Authentication Library - contains methods for interacting with Azure Active Directory and managing user identity

trans-unit.source: Azure Key Vault Library - contains methods for interacting with Azure Key Vault
trans-unit.target: Azure Key Vault Library - contains methods for interacting with Azure Key Vault

trans-unit.source: All three of these packages can be installed using the Package Manager Console using the Install-Package command.
trans-unit.target: All three of these packages can be installed using the Package Manager Console using the Install-Package command.

trans-unit.source: Modify Web.Config
trans-unit.target: Modify Web.Config

trans-unit.source: There are three application settings that need to be added to the web.config file as follows.
trans-unit.target: There are three application settings that need to be added to the web.config file as follows.

trans-unit.source: If you are not going to host your application as an Azure Web App, then you should add the actual ClientId, Client Secret, and Secret URI values to the web.config.
trans-unit.target: If you are not going to host your application as an Azure Web App, then you should add the actual ClientId, Client Secret, and Secret URI values to the web.config.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise leave these dummy values because we will be adding the actual values in the Azure Portal for an additional level of security.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise leave these dummy values because we will be adding the actual values in the Azure Portal for an additional level of security.

trans-unit.source: Add Method to Get an Access Token
trans-unit.target: Add Method to Get an Access Token

trans-unit.source: In order to use the Key Vault API you need an access token.
trans-unit.target: In order to use the Key Vault API you need an access token.

trans-unit.source: The Key Vault Client handles calls to the Key Vault API but you need to supply it with a function that gets the access token.
trans-unit.target: The Key Vault Client handles calls to the Key Vault API but you need to supply it with a function that gets the access token.

trans-unit.source: Following is the code to get an access token from Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: Following is the code to get an access token from Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: This code can go anywhere in your application.
trans-unit.target: This code can go anywhere in your application.

trans-unit.source: I like to add a Utils or EncryptionHelper class.
trans-unit.target: I like to add a Utils or EncryptionHelper class.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Using a Client Secret
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Using a Client Secret

trans-unit.source: Using a Client ID and Client Secret is the easiest way to authenticate an Azure AD application.
trans-unit.target: Using a Client ID and Client Secret is the easiest way to authenticate an Azure AD application.

trans-unit.source: And using it in your web application allows for a separation of duties and more control over your key management.
trans-unit.target: And using it in your web application allows for a separation of duties and more control over your key management.

trans-unit.source: But it does rely on putting the Client Secret in your configuration settings which for some can be as risky as putting the secret that you want to protect in your configuration settings.
trans-unit.target: But it does rely on putting the Client Secret in your configuration settings which for some can be as risky as putting the secret that you want to protect in your configuration settings.

trans-unit.source: See below for a discussion on how to use a Client ID and Certificate instead of Client ID and Client Secret to authenticate the Azure AD application.
trans-unit.target: See below for a discussion on how to use a Client ID and Certificate instead of Client ID and Client Secret to authenticate the Azure AD application.

trans-unit.source: Retrieve the secret on Application Start
trans-unit.target: Retrieve the secret on Application Start

trans-unit.source: Now we need code to call the Key Vault API and retrieve the secret.
trans-unit.target: Now we need code to call the Key Vault API and retrieve the secret.

trans-unit.source: The following code can be put anywhere as long as it is called before you need to use it.
trans-unit.target: The following code can be put anywhere as long as it is called before you need to use it.

trans-unit.source: I have put this code in the Application Start event in the Global.asax so that it runs once on start and makes the secret available for the application.
trans-unit.target: I have put this code in the Application Start event in the Global.asax so that it runs once on start and makes the secret available for the application.

trans-unit.source: Add App Settings in the Azure Portal (optional)
trans-unit.target: Add App Settings in the Azure Portal (optional)

trans-unit.source: If you have an Azure Web App you can now add the actual values for the AppSettings in the Azure Portal.
trans-unit.target: If you have an Azure Web App you can now add the actual values for the AppSettings in the Azure Portal.

trans-unit.source: By doing this, the actual values will not be in the web.config but protected via the Portal where you have separate access control capabilities.
trans-unit.target: By doing this, the actual values will not be in the web.config but protected via the Portal where you have separate access control capabilities.

trans-unit.source: These values will be substituted for the values that you entered in your web.config.
trans-unit.target: These values will be substituted for the values that you entered in your web.config.

trans-unit.source: Make sure that the names are the same.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that the names are the same.

trans-unit.source: ![Application Settings displayed in Azure Portal][1]
trans-unit.target: ![Application Settings displayed in Azure Portal][1]

trans-unit.source: Authenticate with a Certificate instead of a Client Secret
trans-unit.target: Authenticate with a Certificate instead of a Client Secret

trans-unit.source: Another way to authenticate an Azure AD application is by using a Client ID and a Certificate instead of a Client ID and Client Secret.
trans-unit.target: Another way to authenticate an Azure AD application is by using a Client ID and a Certificate instead of a Client ID and Client Secret.

trans-unit.source: Following are the steps to use a Certificate in an Azure Web App:
trans-unit.target: Following are the steps to use a Certificate in an Azure Web App:

trans-unit.source: Get or Create a Certificate
trans-unit.target: Get or Create a Certificate

trans-unit.source: Associate the Certificate with an Azure AD application
trans-unit.target: Associate the Certificate with an Azure AD application

trans-unit.source: Add code to your Web App to use the Certificate
trans-unit.target: Add code to your Web App to use the Certificate

trans-unit.source: Add a Certificate to your Web App
trans-unit.target: Add a Certificate to your Web App

trans-unit.source: **Get or Create a Certificate**
trans-unit.target: **Get or Create a Certificate**

trans-unit.source: For our purposes we will make a test certificate.
trans-unit.target: For our purposes we will make a test certificate.

trans-unit.source: Here are a couple of commands that you can use in a Developer Command Prompt to create a certificate.
trans-unit.target: Here are a couple of commands that you can use in a Developer Command Prompt to create a certificate.

trans-unit.source: Change directory to where you want the cert files to be created.
trans-unit.target: Change directory to where you want the cert files to be created.

trans-unit.source: Make note of the end date and the password for the .pfx (in this example: 07/31/2016 and test123).
trans-unit.target: Make note of the end date and the password for the .pfx (in this example: 07/31/2016 and test123).

trans-unit.source: You will need them below.
trans-unit.target: You will need them below.

trans-unit.source: For more information on creating a test certificate, see [How to: Create Your Own Test Certificate](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-in/library/ff699202.aspx)
trans-unit.target: For more information on creating a test certificate, see [How to: Create Your Own Test Certificate](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-in/library/ff699202.aspx)

trans-unit.source: **Associate the Certificate with an Azure AD application**
trans-unit.target: **Associate the Certificate with an Azure AD application**

trans-unit.source: Now that you have a certificate, you need to associate it with an Azure AD application.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have a certificate, you need to associate it with an Azure AD application.

trans-unit.source: But the Azure Management Portal does not support this right now.
trans-unit.target: But the Azure Management Portal does not support this right now.

trans-unit.source: Instead you have to use Powershell.
trans-unit.target: Instead you have to use Powershell.

trans-unit.source: Following are the commands that you need to run:
trans-unit.target: Following are the commands that you need to run:

trans-unit.source: After you have run these commands, you can see the application in Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: After you have run these commands, you can see the application in Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: If you don't see the application at first, search for "Applications my company owns" instead of "Applications my company uses".
trans-unit.target: If you don't see the application at first, search for "Applications my company owns" instead of "Applications my company uses".

trans-unit.source: To learn more about Azure AD Application Objects and ServicePrincipal Objects, see [Application Objects and Service Principal Objects](../active-directory/active-directory-application-objects.md)
trans-unit.target: To learn more about Azure AD Application Objects and ServicePrincipal Objects, see [Application Objects and Service Principal Objects](../active-directory/active-directory-application-objects.md)

trans-unit.target: **Add code to your Web App to use the Certificate**

trans-unit.source: Now we will add code to your Web App to access the cert and use it for authentication.
trans-unit.target: Now we will add code to your Web App to access the cert and use it for authentication.

trans-unit.target: And that we are supplying 'false' to the Find method because we are using a test cert.

trans-unit.target: Next is code that uses the CertificateHelper and creates a ClientAssertionCertificate which is needed for authentication.

trans-unit.source: **Add a Certificate to your Web App**
trans-unit.target: **Add a Certificate to your Web App**

trans-unit.source: Adding a Certificate to your Web App is a simple two-step process.
trans-unit.target: Adding a Certificate to your Web App is a simple two-step process.

trans-unit.source: First, go to the Azure Portal and navigate to your Web App.
trans-unit.target: First, go to the Azure Portal and navigate to your Web App.

trans-unit.source: On the Settings blade for your Web App, click on the entry for "Custom domains and SSL".
trans-unit.target: On the Settings blade for your Web App, click on the entry for "Custom domains and SSL".

trans-unit.source: On the blade that opens you will be able to upload the Certificate that you created above, KVWebApp.pfx, make sure that you remember the password for the pfx.
trans-unit.target: On the blade that opens you will be able to upload the Certificate that you created above, KVWebApp.pfx, make sure that you remember the password for the pfx.

trans-unit.source: ![Adding a Certificate to a Web App in the Azure Portal][2]
trans-unit.target: ![Adding a Certificate to a Web App in the Azure Portal][2]

trans-unit.source: The last thing that you need to do is to add an Application Setting to your Web App that has the name WEBSITE\_LOAD\_CERTIFICATES and a value of *.
trans-unit.target: The last thing that you need to do is to add an Application Setting to your Web App that has the name WEBSITE\_LOAD\_CERTIFICATES and a value of *.

trans-unit.source: This will ensure that all Certificates are loaded.
trans-unit.target: This will ensure that all Certificates are loaded.

trans-unit.source: If you wanted to load only the Certificates that you have uploaded, then you can enter a comma-separated list of their thumbprints.
trans-unit.target: If you wanted to load only the Certificates that you have uploaded, then you can enter a comma-separated list of their thumbprints.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about adding a Certificate to a Web App, see [Using Certificates in Azure Websites Applications](https://azure.microsoft.com/blog/2014/10/27/using-certificates-in-azure-websites-applications/)
trans-unit.target: To learn more about adding a Certificate to a Web App, see [Using Certificates in Azure Websites Applications](https://azure.microsoft.com/blog/2014/10/27/using-certificates-in-azure-websites-applications/)

trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.target: For programming references, see [Azure Key Vault C# Client API Reference](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn903628.aspx).
